app.sortby.name: Name
ari.advice:
- Your silver card is probably the most powerful tool in your arsenal. It can force your opponents to play around it, as long as you are close enough to the action.
- Use your gold card to protect friendly units and to set up future attacks.
- Both of your green branches are great for mobility and setting uo attacks, as long as you can play around their limitations.
ari.lore: When Arien's war galley was ambushed and destroyed by an unknown vessel, he blamed himself for the loss of the crew. He now offers his blade and his knowledge of the arcane to anyone who can help him find his nemesis.
bro.advice:
- If you expect trouble, play your silver card.
- Use fast travel and attacks with built-in movement to compensate for your low mobility.
- Don't let yourself get stranded away from the action.
- An attack card in hand can be as much of a threat as an attack card played.
- Do not underestimate your support options.
bro.lore: Brogan regained his sense in the midst of battle. War drums resonated with the pounding in his ears, and the elf made a note to quit Drakenhuff Grof. As the enemy mounted their charge, he reached behind him: first feeling the strings of his lute, then the handle of his axe.
tig.advice:
- The best defense is not to get hit at all.
- Use mobility and your silver card to stay alive.
- Ranged attacks and discard effects are the main threats to you.  
- Enemies can deny you your basic attacks by blocking a crucial space. Do not let them!
tig.lore: Tigerclaw is as elusive as a shadow in the desert. A useful quality to have, when half the continent wants you dead and the other half wants you quartered first and then dead.
was.advice:
- Your gold card carries the most value when you are close to the enemy heroes. However, you do not have the capacity to endure consistent damage. Know when to disengage.
- Your silver card is a versatile tool that can be used to deny enemies access to minions.
- You have access to many tools that can disrupt enemy positioning, and deny attacks when used in the right moment.
was.lore: As all heiresses to the throne of the Gilded Empire, Wasp was exiled from the palace as soon as she could hold a dagger. She needs to learn to control her powers before she can face the ultimate challenge and claim her birthright.
sab.advice:
- You become considerably stronger when you are near friendly minions. Stay in formation!
- Your gold card is a great defensive counter to non-ranged attacks.
- Your main weakness is your below-average defense, paired with a lack of self-heal.
- Position in a way to be able to use your silver.
- Your choice of red branch will strongly impact your avenues to victory. Choose wisely.
sab.lore: One lesson that Sabina learned when serving as a condottiere, was that any weapon could misfire, and any armor could crack, but true comradery would never fail. When an old friend called in a favor, she didn't hesitate.
xar.advice:
- Offense is the best defense. Use your gold card to dissuade the enemy from attacking.
- Your silver card is extremely versatile. It can be used to farm minions more easily, assist allies, and set up ambushes.
- You can use high movement on your primary red card to pursue wounded enemy heroes and finish them off with your gold card.
xar.lore: Xargatha was the high priestess of the sacred shrine when it was desecrated and the holy relic was stolen. Her anger and grief were so powerful that they transformed her into a monster. She abandoned the temple to find the thieves and return the relic.
dod.advice:
- Your main weakness is your low defense. Keep this in mind when leveling up.
- You are stronger when there are many empty minion spawn points in the battle zone, which can be achieved by defeating minions or displacing them through other means.
- Some cards let you remove friendly minions. Use this to control when the lane is pushed.
dod.lore: Dodger hated delving through the dusty tomes. It was always the more practical aspect of dark magic that fascinated her, so when a daemon offered to complete her training by bypassing the boring formalities, it took a mirror for her to realize that there was fine print in that contract.
row.advice:
- Your silver is most effective when jumping to a space adjacent to multiple enemy units.
- Your best chance to defeat an enemy hero with your gold card is when they have a low-defense card in their discard.
- Talk to your teammates to maximize the impact of your red cards.
row.lore: From a young age, Rowenna dreamed of becoming a knight. She trained relentlessly, honing her combat skills and mastering the code of chivalry. Whether facing monstrous beasts or overwhelming odds, Rowenna stands unwavering, ready to defend the innocent, support her comrades, and lead her troops to victory.
gar.advice:
- Attacking second with your gold card can be an easy way to deal extra damage.
- Your silver card can be very effective against heroes with high movement values.
- With certain builds, enemies may be forced to prioritize you as a target when you have a card in the discard. Use this to your advantage.
gar.lore: Garrus was the reigning champion of the Arena until his defeat at the hands of a stranger, who tricked him into losing his temper. He roams the land, seeking to regain his title and his honor. They say that his shield can deflect a point-blank ballista shot. No one has ever dared to check if it's true.
bai.advice:
- The psychological effect of the bounty marker should not be underestimated.
- Your silver card can save allies, disrupt enemies, and help clear minion waves faster.
bai.lore: I wouldn't go around asking questions about Bain. Shady character, that one. Some say he is a nobleman looking for his lost sister, some say he is just an ordinary drunk. Drunk or not, he is the best shot this side of the desert. Unless you want him for a job, stay clear of him, partner!
whi.advice:
- Your main weakness is in your limited mobility. Use your green cards as a workaround.
- Your gold card discard can help your allies to defeat enemy heroes, or to scare them away.
- Time your gold card correctly; used at the wrong moment, it can help the target escape.
- You silver card makes you really hard to kill, as long as a nearby enemy is wounded.
whi.lore: Whisper was the Grand Judicator of the Underkingdom when he condemned a powerful noble attempting to escape punishment. Refusing to look the other way, he was blinded and left to die. As if he wasn't dead in the first place! The fools!
mis.advice:
- Mise is one of the quirkiest heroes in the game. Most of your cards do not follow the usual conventions.
- You only have one attack card. Make it count.
- Your gold card is both your best defense and best movement, but it cannot defeat minions.
- Your role is closely tied to your choice of green card. One branch helps with pushing the lane, while the other is more fight-oriented.
- When used in the right moment, your silver card can both deny minion and protect allies.
mis.lore: Misa will fight against overwhelming odds to protect her master. Unfortunately, she has yet to find anyone worthy of her blade and loyalty.
urs.advice:
- Ursafar is the best brawler in the game. Use this advantage to stay in the thick of things.
- You are at your best when the enemies come to you. Don't waste your precious movement actions on pointless pursuit.
- Your biggest weakness is your low mobility. Your worst nightmare is to end up on the wrong side of the board after the lane is pushed.
- The best way to get enraged is by attacking an enemy, or by defending with your silver card. Build your items accordingly.
urs.lore: When Ursafar roars, the frost beasts cower in their icy caves, and the tribesmen place fresh fish outside their igloos to appease the great bear.
sil.advice:
- Your ranged attacks are among the most powerful, but they are fairly easy to disrupt. Know your weaknesses and don't let the enemies surprise you.
- Being adjacent to enemy units disables a large portion of your abilities. Keep your distance!
- While it may feel tempting to stay away from the fight, don't leave your allies alone. They rely on your firepower and utility skills.
sil.lore: Silverarrow never imagined she would leave the Forest until the Oracle uttered the prophecy. The hardest step of any path is the very first one; after that, you just keep moving.
min.advice:
- End movement in straight lines from enemy heroes to utilize your smoke bomb.
- Your gold card can be powered up even if your red card was used for movement or defense.
- Mines cover more ground but are less reliable. Grenades require precise timing.
min.lore: The monks of the Order of the Dragon once worshipped the ancient beasts. But with their patrons gone, Min and his brothers had to adopt more practical applications of their beliefs
mra.advice:
- Mrak specializes in area denial and control.
- You are difficult to take down, especially if you level up the alternative red branch.
- If you struggle with low mobility, the alternative green branch will get you rolling.
mra.lore: In the shadows beneath the old cobblestone bridge, where whispers of forgotten tales and echoes of passing travelers intertwine, resides Mrak. As befits a retired troll geomancer, he isn’t particularly fond of unexpected guests.
cut.advice:
- Both your gold and red cards can be tricky to land, so use your other tools to set them up.
- Your silver allows you to move long distances at low initiative, enabling aggressive plays.
- Primary blue and green rely on timing but can force tough choices on your opponents.
- Your alternate green branch offers reliable mobility and helps set up minion takes.
- Your alt blue can get you extra coin, if you have an action to spare.
cut.lore: The daring exploits of Cutter, the captain of the skyship Black Sparrow, are the crowd favorite in every tavern across the continent! She traded her life as a noble-born debutante for that of a swashbuckler and a scoundrel.
tri.advice:
- Plan ahead when placing your turret to avoid spending actions on moving it each round.
- Use the turret to tactically block key spaces.
- Your level-up choices significantly influence your strategic options, so choose wisely.
tri.lore: Trinkets is really smart — well, by kobold standards, that is. He was expelled from Drakenhuff after almost destroying the entire city. When he’s not busy constructing doomsday devices or unearthing spare parts, he’s tinkering with his automated turret.
tal.advice:
- More than any other hero, Tali relies on her team to do the right thing.
- Know when you can afford to discard.
- You have a wide array of options, but will have to make hard choices when leveling up.
tal.lore: When she heard their voices for the first time, no one believed her. Tali held no grudges. When the frost beasts threatened her tribe, she did what she had to do. And when the village was saved, she left — the spirits were calling her.
swi.advice:
- Threatening to attack both an enemy hero and a minion forces the hero to react.
- The sniper rifle is more effective for pushing, while the shotgun excels against heroes.
- Sometimes, it’s better to use your gold card to defeat an adjacent minion.
- If you’re having difficulty landing attacks, rely on your blue and green Tactician skills.
swi.lore: When Swift’s application to the Royal Fleet Academy was declined, she didn’t give up on her dreams of roaming the skies. She joined the mobile scouts just before the Last War and earned her place as the best shot of her regiment.
wuk.advice:
- Plan ahead. Where will you need those trees next turn? And what about in the next round?
- You can use trees to block key spaces.
- Mobility is not your strongest attribute, so move along when the wave is about to push.
wuk.lore: The grove does not need protection; Wuk simply chooses to stay here. Trees make the best company when you prefer not to be disturbed. If you’re daring enough to enter his domain, whatever you do, don’t touch the trees!
han.advice:
- Your gold card will help you stay alive as long as you have an escape route.
- Your silver can assist your allies in landing attacks, but it can also be used on enemy heroes to force them to move early when they intended to go later.
- It’s often worth strategizing with your team, even if it reveals your plans. You have many ways to set up your allies for success.
han.lore: A day without mischief is a day wasted. Free from his brother’s wise guidance, Hanu roams the ruins of the old Atlantean capital, playing tricks on any would-be explorer reckless enough to enter the domain of the Great Tricker.
bry.advice:
- When the condition isn’t met, your cards still have an effect. The non-conditional part is less powerful but much more reliable.
- Coordinate with your team — they can help you unlock the full potential of your cards.
- Your red ranged attack makes you a better pusher but also leaves you more vulnerable.
- Use the silver to help your team get minions.
bry.lore: Born in a remote mountain settlement, Brunn was expected to become a healer like her mother. However, her true passion lay in braving the surrounding wilderness. When a mysterious plague struck and even her mother fell ill, Bryn set out for the fabled grove where the only cure could be found.
mor.advice:
- Use your zombies to zone and block enemy heroes, but be cautious not to obstruct friendly heroes' movement.
- You are considerably stronger at higher levels and your farm blue can get you there faster.
mor.lore: Mortimer the Awakener wields an ancient relic from a bygone age, forged from obsidian and infused with the pure essence of Death Metal. As he plucks the strings of his isntrument, the fallen souls of his fans rise!
wid.advice:
- Pyro is Widget’s dragon companion, who you can summon using her silver card.
- While Pyro is on the board, Widget becomes significantly more powerful.
- Although Pyro is represented by a miniature, he counts as a token and can be removed by a “Clear” action — keep him out of trouble.
- Winning with this duo comes from properly positioning Pyro and timing your gold attack.
wid.lore: Widget’s tribe clung to the old ways — quite unusual for kobolds. The young warrior paid little attention to fairy tales or the dusty prophecies about the dragons’ return, until one journey led her to a strange egg. When it hatched, she named the youngling Pyro.
sno.advice:
- Plan ahead. Readjusting rune placement costs you an action.
- The higher your level, the more versatile you become. Ensure you get enough coins.
sno.lore: Like any other self-respecting dwarf, Snorri never planned to go on an adventure. That plan went south when his former apprentice strayed from the path of tradition and delved into the murky realm of experimental runic graffiti. Snorri needed to adjust his plans.
raz.advice:
- At the start of the game or when you respawn, there's only one of you placed on the board.
- Once a copy is spawned, you cannot spawn it again with your gold card.
- The more of you in play, the stronger you are.
- Your survival often relies on keeping your clones within the radius of your silver card.
raz.lore: A lesser-known fact about magical mirrors is that they break easily. Razzle froze as her mirror shattered into a myriad of twinkling fragments, as if a troupe of mischievous pixies had decided to test their acrobatic skills. When the silence fell, she found herself surrounded by a host of identical faces, each wearing an expression of utter confusion.
gyd.advice:
- When casting spells, treat the actions on spell cards like any other actions.
- Keep spells you cannot cast yet in a separate facedown pile while they remain in the spellbook.
gyd.lore: Gydion the Archwizard is an odd blend of ancient wisdom and forgetfulness that could make a goldfish look like a meticulous archivist. Despite this, he has an uncanny knack for invoking the right spells at exactly the right moment.
neb.advice:
- Keep as many opponents within range of your gold as possible to maximize your options.
- Your silver allows you to rearrange resolved cards of other heroes, which is useful for your gold.
- Your green cards, paired with your silver, are your main mobility tool. Play them early.
neb.lore: NebKher is an enigmatic traveler, draped in exotic garb, his face concealed behind a terrifying mask. Those who have encountered him speak of his unnatural powers over the minds of living beings.
ign.advice:
- Always aim to have a target, regardless of which side the tie-breaker coin lands on.
- The effects tied to your team's color are less likely to be thwarted by an untimely coin flip.
- Your silver card allows you to take full control of your powers, but it makes you significantly more vulnerable while in use.
ign.lore: There is a fine line between genius and madness, and Ignatia is the living proof of this. The dwarven fire-mage is as powerful as she is unpredictable, just like the forces she commands.
tak.advice:
- You have access to three gold cards, instead of one, though only one of them is in your hand (until you reach the ultimate).
- Plan ahead, and try to have the exact gold card that you need in your hand at the exact time when you need it.
- A lot of your skills require allies to have discarded cards. Talk to your allies and make sure you work together as a team.
tak.lore: Takahide rose to become a feared warlord, leading his armies from victory to victory — until a lone warrior refused to obey his orders. Now, he is consumed by a relentless obsession to crush his warrior for defying him.
emm.advice:
- The effect of your gold card impacts everyone, so be cautious not to endanger your allies.
- Use your silver to boost mobility, but remember it makes you more vulnerable.
emm.lore: Emmitt the Traveler is a visitor from the distant future. Armed with a portable time-travel device, he fights to restore fractured timelines, using both his sharp mind and the occasional power-fist punch, appearing where and when he is needed most.
ari-silver.text:
**This turn:** Enemy heroes in radius cannot perform skills.
_(Spell Break will not stop an attack action.)_
ari-gold.text:
Target a unit adjacent to you.
Before the attack: You may move another unit that is adjacent to the target 1 space.
_(“Another unit” does not include you.)_
ari-gold-h.text:
Target a hero adjacent to you.
Before the attack: You may move a minion that is adjacent to the target 1 space.
ari-red-i.text:
Target a unit in range.
After the attack: Push up to one token, or an enemy unit, adjacent to you 1 space.
ari-red-ii.text:
Target a unit in range.
After the attack: Push up to one token, or an enemy unit, adjacent to you 1 space.
ari-red-iii.text:
Target a unit in range.
After the attack: Move the target up to 1 space. Push up to one token, or an enemy unit, adjacent to you 1 space.
ari-red-ii-alt.text:
Target a unit adjacent to you.
Beforethe attack: One enemy hero in any of the 3 spaces in a straight line directly behind the target discards a card, or is defeated.
ari-red-iii-alt.text:
Target a unit adjacent to you.
Beforethe attack: One enemy hero in any of the 5 spaces in a straight line directly behind the target discards a card, or is defeated.
May repeat once on a different target.
ari-green-i.text: Place yourself into a space in range without a spawn point and not adjacent to an empty spawn point.
ari-green-ii.text: Place yourself into a space in range without a spawn point and not adjacent to an empty spawn point.
ari-green-iii.text: Place yourself into a space in range without a spawn point.
ari-green-ii-alt.text:
Swap with a minion or a friendly hero in range.
_(Swap places with the target. This is not movement.)_
ari-green-iii-alt.text: Swap with a unit or a token in range,
ari-blue-i.text:
Ignore all minion defense modifiers.
_(This includes your minions, as well as the enemy minions.)_
ari-blue-ii.text:
Ignore all minion defense modifiers.
**This turn:** You are immune to all other enemy attack actions.
ari-blue-iii.text:
Ignore all minion defense modifiers.
**This turn:** You are immune to all other enemy attack actions.
ari-blue-ii-alt.text:
**This turn:** Enemies in radius cannot move more than 1 space with a movement action.
_(Enemies who start movement out of radius are unaffected.)_
ari-blue-iii-alt.text: **This turn and next turn:** Enemies in radius cannot move more than 1 space with a movement action.
ari-purple-iv.text: After you perform a basic skill, you may trigger a minion battle in the battle zone you are in.
bro-silver.text:
**Choose one –**
- **This round**: You and friendly units in radius cannot be moved, pushed, swapped, or forced to move by enemy heroes.
- If your discard is empty, retrieve this card.
bro-gold.text:
Target a unit adjacent to you.
After the attack: Move into the space it occupied, if able.
bro-gold-h.text:
Target a hero adjacent to you.
After the attack: Move into the space it occupied, if able.
bro-red-i.text:
Before the attack: Move 2 spaces in a straight line to a space adjacent to an enemy unit, then target that unit.
_(If you cannot make this move, you cannot attack.)_
bro-red-ii.text: Before the attack: Move 2 or 3 spaces in a straight line to a space adjacent to an enemy unit, then target that unit.
bro-red-iii.text: Before the attack: Move 2, 3 or 4 spaces in a straight line to a space adjacent to an enemy unit, then target that unit.
bro-red-ii-alt.text:
Before the attack: You may discard a card. If you do, +2 ::range:: Range.
Target a unit in range.
bro-red-iii-alt.text:
Before the attack: You may discard a card. +2 ::range:: Range if you have a card in the discard.
Target a unit in range.
bro-green-i.text: **This round:** When any friendly minion in radius would be defeated, you may discard a card. If you do, the minion is not defeated.
bro-green-ii.text: **This round:** When any friendly minion in radius would be defeated, you may discard a card. If you do, the minion is not defeated.
bro-green-iii.text: **This round:** When any friendly minion in radius would be defeated, you may discard a card. If you do, the minion is not defeated.
bro-green-ii-alt.text: A friendly hero in range may retrieve a discarded card if either you, or that hero, is adjacent to an enemy unit.
bro-green-iii-alt.text: A friendly hero in range may retrieve a resolved or discarded card if either you, or that hero, is adjacent to an enemy unit.
bro-blue-i.text:
**Choose one —**
- Remove a token adjacent to you.
- Push an enemy minion adjacent to you up to 2 spaces.
bro-blue-ii.text:
Move up to 1 space, then **Choose one —**
- Remove a token adjacent to you.
- Push an enemy minion adjacent to you up to 2 spaces.
bro-blue-iii.text:
Move up to 1 space, then **Choose one —**
- Remove a token adjacent to you.
- Push an enemy minion adjacent to you up to 2 spaces.
bro-blue-ii-alt.text: An enemy hero adjacent to you, who has played an attack card this turn, discards a card, if able.
bro-blue-iii-alt.text: An enemy hero adjacent to you, who has played an attack card this turn, discards a card, or is defeated.
bro-purple-iv.text: You count as 2 minions during minion battle. If you would be removed during minion battle, you lose the push instead.
tig-silver.text: If you are adjacent to an obstacle, place yourself into a space in radius not adjacent to an enemy unit. if you do, **Next turn:** You are immune, and may move through units.
tig-gold.text:
Before the attack: Move 2 spaces in a straight line through an enemy unit; target that unit.
_(If you cannot make this move, you cannot attack)_.
tig-gold-h.text: Before the attack: Move 2 spaces in a straight line through an enemy hero; target that hero.
tig-red-i.text:
Target a unit adjacent to you.
After the attack: You may move 1 space.
tig-red-ii.text:
Before the attack: You may move 1 space.
Target a unit adjacent to you.
After the attack: If you did not move before the attack, you may move 1 space.
tig-red-iii.text:
Before the attack: You may move 1 space.
Target a unit adjacent to you.
After the attack: You may move 1 space.
tig-red-ii-alt.text:
Target a unit adjacent to you. +2 ::attack:: Attack if a friendly unit is adjacent to the target.
_(A “friendly unit” is another hero or a minion on your team.)_
tig-red-iii-alt.text:
Target a unit adjacent to you. +3 ::attack:: Attack and this attack cannot be blocked, if a friendly unit is adjacent to the target.
_("Block" is a keyword - the target hero can still defend!)_
tig-green-i.text:
Move up to 2 spaces, then take up to 1 coin from an enemy hero adjacent to you.
Then move 2 spaces in a straight line, if able.
tig-green-ii.text:
Move up to 2 spaces, then take up to 2 coins from an enemy hero adjacent to you.
Then move 2 spaces in a straight line, if able.
tig-green-iii.text:
Move up to 2 spaces, then take up to 3 coins from an enemy hero adjacent to you.
Then move 2 spaces in a straight line, if able.
tig-green-ii-alt.text:
Give a hero in range a ::marker_poison:: poison marker.
Each ::initiative:: Initiative and ::attack:: Attack item of a hero with a poison marker reduces that value by 1, instead of increasing it by 1.
tig-green-iii-alt.text:
Give a hero in range a ::marker_poison:: poison marker.
Each ::initiative:: Initiative, ::attack:: Attack and ::defense:: Defense item of a hero with a poison marker reduces that value by 1, instead of increasing it by 1.
tig-blue-ii.text:
Block a ranged attack.
If you do, you may move 2 spaces in a straight line.
tig-blue-iii.text:
Block a ranged attack.
If you do, you may move 2 spaces in a straight line a.d you may swap this card with a card from your hand.
tig-blue-ii-alt.text:
Block a non-ranged attack.
The attacker discards a card, if able.
tig-blue-iii-alt.text:
Block a non-ranged attack.
The attacker discards a card, or is defeated.
tig-purple-iv.text: If you are immune: Before you perform (or repeat) any action, move up to 2 spaces; after you perform a basic attack, you may repeat it once a different target.
was-silver.text: **This turn:** Enemy units in radius cannot move or fast travel out of radius. Enemy units outside of radius cannot move or fast travel into radius.
was-gold.text:
Target a unit adjacent to you.
After the attack: Cancel active effects on skill cards of enemy heroes adjacent to you.
**This turn:** Enemy heroes adjacent to you cannot perform skill actions.
was-gold-h.text:
Target a hero adjacent to you.
After the attack: Cancel active effects on skill cards of enemy heroes adjacent to you.
**This turn:** Those heroes cannot perform skill actions.
was-red-i.text:
Target a unit adjacent to you.
Before the attack: Up to one enemy hero adjacent to you, except the target, discards a card, if able.
was-red-ii.text:
Target a unit adjacent to you.
Before the attack: Up to one enemy hero in radius, except the target, discards a card, if able.
_(Even though there is a radius icon, this is a non-ranged attack and the original target od the attack must be adjacent to you.)_
was-red-iii.text:
Target a unit adjacent to you.
Before the attack: Up to one enemy hero in radius, except the target, discards a card, or is defeated.
was-red-ii-alt.text:
Target a unit in range, not in a straight line.
_(Adjacent units are in a straight line as well.)_
was-red-iii-alt.text:
Target a unit in range, not in a straight line.
If you defeat an enemy hero, may repeat once.
was-green-i.text: If the attacker is not adjacent to you, block a ranged attack.
was-green-ii.text:
If the attacker is not adjacent to you, block a ranged attack.
If you do, the attacker discards a card, if able.
was-green-iii.text:
If the attacker is not adjacent to you, block a ranged attack.
If you do, the attacker discards a card, if able.
**This turn:** You are immune to ranged attacks or heroes not adjacent to you.
was-green-ii-alt.text: Place a unit or a token in range, which is not in a straight line, into a space adjacent to you.
was-green-iii-alt.text:
Place a unit or a token in range, which is not in a straight line, into a space adjacent to you.
May repeat once.
was-blue-i.text: Move a unit, or a token, not adjacent to you and in radius, up to 1 space, without moving it away from you, or closer to you.
was-blue-ii.text:
Move a unit, or a token, not adjacent to you and in radius, up to 1 space, without moving it away from you, or closer to you.
May repeat once.
was-blue-iii.text:
Move a unit, or a token, not adjacent to you and in radius, up to 1 space, without moving it away from you, or closer to you.
May repeat up to two times.
was-blue-ii-alt.text: Push every enemy unit adjacent to you 2 spaces; each enemy hero that was stopped by an obstacle discards a card, if able.
was-blue-iii-alt.text: Push every enemy unit adjacent to you 3 spaces; each enemy hero that was stopped by an obstacle discards a card, if able.
was-purple-iv.text: After you perform a basic skill, one enemy hero in play discards a card, if able.
sab-silver.text:
You may swap with a friendly minion adjacent to you.
**This turn:** You and friendly heroes in radius gain +1 ::defense:: Defense if adjacent to one or more friendly minions.
sab-gold.text:
Target a unit in range.
After the attack: Push the target 1 space, if it is adjacent to you.
_(A unit pushed into an obstacle will stop. This is a valid push)_
sab-gold-h.text:
Target a hero adjacent to you.
After the attack: Push the target 1 space.
sab-red-i.text: Target a unit in range, not adjacent to you.
sab-red-ii.text:
Target a unit in range, not adjacent to you.
+2 ::attack:: Attack if the target hero played an attack card this turn.
_(A revealed card is "played" even if it's not resolved yet.)_
sab-red-iii.text:
Target a unit in range.
+2 ::attack:: Attack if the target hero played an attack card this turn.
sab-red-ii-alt.text:
Target a unit in range.
After the attack: If you defeated a minion with this attack, and there is no enemy hero in range, you may remove a non-heavy minion adjacent to you.
_(You gain no coins for removing a minion.)_
sab-red-iii-alt.text:
Target a unit in range.
After the attack: If you defeated a minion with this attack, and there is no enemy hero in range, you may remove a non-heavy minion in range.
sab-green-i.text:

faq-ari-hGd1QYgj.question: Does Arien’s attack require a hero behind the target?
faq-ari-hGd1QYgj.answer: No, this effect is errata’d to say “up to 1”.
faq-ari-p7QWkUE0.question: Do Arien’s green skill cards perform movement?
faq-ari-p7QWkUE0.answer: No. The primary Green **places** Arien, the alternative Green **swaps**. These are not movement and are not restricted by effects that restrict movement.
faq-ari-5OTmpo8i.question: What do Arien's alternative blue skill cards restrict?
faq-ari-5OTmpo8i.answer:
This card restricts the movement, by a movement action, of Heroes in radius. It will **not** affect pushing, swapping, or placement effects (including fast travel!). It also will **not** restrict movement as part of other actions (such as Brogan’s Primary Red or Tigerclaw’s Primary Green).
Additionally, because movement restrictions are checked at the beginning of a movement, a Hero can freely move into and through the radius of Arien’s effect without being affected.
faq-bai-g0LnJfSb.question: What does a ::marker_bounty:: Bounty Marker from Bain’s Gold (Dead or Alive) do?
faq-bai-g0LnJfSb.answer: A Bounty Marker doesn’t do anything by itself. If Bain’s enemy is defeated that round, they spend an additional life counter (and return the Marker). At the end of the round, the Bounty Marker is returned. If Bain is defeated, the Marker is not returned.
faq-bro-UGm22plF.question: Is the movement required on Brogan's Gold?
faq-bro-UGm22plF.answer:
Yes. Unless otherwise indicated, card text is mandatory. Brogan must move into the space where the target was, if he is able to (if it is empty).
- Note: generally the space will be empty if he defeated the target, but several primary defense cards, like Cutter’s Silver (_Grappling Bolt_) and Swift’s Alt Blue (_Tactical Jump_), may move the target out of the space, allowing (requiring) Brogan to move into it.
faq-bro-2Mz0rGtI.question: Why would I want to retrieve Brogan’s Silver? Doesn’t this do nothing?
faq-bro-2Mz0rGtI.answer: In Guards of Atlantis, your cards are also your health. Retrieving Brogan’s Silver makes him more resilient to attacks and discard effects later in the round.
faq-bro-jMK17229.question: What’s the difference between “moved” and forced to move” on Brogan’s Silver?
faq-bro-jMK17229.answer: “Force to move” is an effect that says “an enemy hero moves X” (and you would normally choose). “Moved” is an effect that says “move an enemy hero X” (and the opponent who played the effect would choose how to move you).
faq-bro-fbDz04ez.question: Does Brogan’s Primary Red attack require movement?
faq-bro-fbDz04ez.answer:
Yes! If Brogan cannot move 2 spaces in a straight line to a space adjacent to an enemy unit, the effect will “fizzle” — stop resolving — and he will not attack. A crafty opponent can anticipate and deny this attack with clever positioning.
- Brogan can charge next to an immune unit, at which point his attack would fizzle.
- Brogan can charge through Min’s Smoke Bomb Token, since the Smoke Bomb only prevents targeting across the Smoke Bomb and Brogan would not target until after the movement.
faq-bro-U8USFZ6w.question: Does Brogan’s Primary Green work during Minion Battle?
faq-bro-U8USFZ6w.answer: No. Minions are not “defeated” in Minion Battle, they are removed.
faq-bro-6XDWvftE.question: Can Brogan’s Alernative Blue target a Hero who has played an attack card but not attacked?
faq-bro-6XDWvftE.answer: Yes: it only checks for Heroes that “played” an attack card, regardless of whether they’ve resolved the action, which action they performed, and even whether this is still their card for the turn (it will “remember” whether they have played a card, even if it is discarded or switched for another card by an effect).
faq-cut-J96IkUe0.question: What can Cutter’s Silver (Grappling Bolt) target?
faq-cut-J96IkUe0.answer: Any obstacle (units, tokens, terrain, or other miniatures) can be targeted by Grappling Bolt. This includes immune units as well as the terrain spaces around the edge of the map (she can grapple onto the water).
faq-dod-DYMXRSjX.question: What is an “empty minion spawn point in the battle zone”?
faq-dod-DYMXRSjX.answer: Dodger’s magic (thematically) grows stronger as minions are defeated. Many of her cards check for “empty minion spawn points in the battle zone.” These are the minion spawn points printed on the board, but only the ones in the current battle zone — there is only 1 battle zone (2, on the 2-lane map). Only empty spaces (with **nothing** on them) are counted.
faq-dod-36mZD5jZ.question: Why and how would Dodger remove her own friendly minions?
faq-dod-36mZD5jZ.answer: Several of Dodger’s cards become more powerful with empty minion spawn points near her. Some of her cards allow her to remove her own friendly minions, which helps her achieve this more quickly (and may remove a minion that an opponent will soon defeat anyway). Removing a friendly minion does _not_ earn Dodger coins. Heroes can never **attack** their own friendly units.
faq-dod-uU82U9DL.question: When does Dodger’s Tier III Primary Red card prevent retrieval?
faq-dod-uU82U9DL.answer: As soon as the unit is targeted. If a hero defended with a defense action that retrieves a card, they would not be able to retrieve the card.
faq-dod-73Ipv84g.question: When Dodger uses another card’s action with her Alt Blue cards, what weird things can happen?
faq-dod-73Ipv84g.answer:
Here are some possibilities:
- Active effects Dodger copies will work normally. The effect remains, even if the originally copied card changes state or the hero is defeated.
- If Dodger copies cards that specifically refer to Tokens, she uses those tokens as those heroes would (such as Min’s grenade or smoke bomb, or Wuk’s trees).
- However, when placing Tokens with special properties, the properties are still defined by the originating Hero’s card, since Heroes do not “own” Tokens. The two big examples are that Tali’s Alt Green (_Glacial Barrier_) places a Token that has an Initiative penalty to Tali’s enemies (not Dodger’s), and Min’s Blue (_Trip Mine_) places Mines as Dodger chooses, but they would force discards against Min’s enemies (not Dodger’s). So, probably don’t copy these cards.
- Dodger can copy Trinkets’ cards to remove and/or place the Turret.
- If Dodger copies an action that says “this card”, it means the card with the printed ability, not Dodger’s. She cannot copy Brogan’s Silver (_Bullwark_), for example, then retrieve her card.
- Dodger’s Alt Blue is a skill card, so some card resolutions may happen differently. Examples:
  - If Dodger copies a non-ranged attack, she is performing a non-ranged attack (even though her Blue card is an area-skill).
  - If Dodger copies an attack and Bain blocks with his Primary Green (_Close Call_), Dodger would not pick up her Blue card, since she is not playing an attack card.
  - If Dodger copies Trinkets’ Primary Red (_Makeshift Minigun_), she will gain a range bonus. If she is subsequently hit by Wasp’s Gold (_Dazzling Dagger_), the active +range bonus copied from Trinkets is canceled).
- If Dodger copies Xargatha’s Green (_Charming Aura_), both heroes may try to “convert” the surrounding minions: these are resolved starting with the team shown on the tie-breaker coin, without flipping it (see Rulebook, p. 18). This means that the tiebreaker coin team may convert several minions to friendly, then the non-tiebreaker team may convert them back, as well as any others that were already enemies.
- Dodger cannot copy the card of an immune hero.
faq-dod-uF7N41Hk.question: If Dodger removes her friendly Heavy Minion with her Primary Green card, which happens first, the push or a chance to collect a coin?
faq-dod-uF7N41Hk.answer: Pushing the Lane happens immediately, even in the middle of an action. If Dodger is down to only the Heavy Minion for her team and she plays her Primary Green, she would be able to remove the Heavy (since it is no longer immune), would not collect coins (it is removing, not defeating), and the Lane would immediately Push. This means the “Battle Zone” has now shifted to the new zone, which does not have empty minion spawn points, so she will not normally be able to collect a coin from the effect on her card.
faq-dod-9oAe2b05.question: What minions can Dodger respawn with her Alternative Green card?
faq-dod-9oAe2b05.answer:
She can return a friendly defeated/removed minion of any type to any spawn point. 
- It need not be a matching minion type or color: if her friendly ranged minion is defeated, Dodger could respawn it on an enemy melee minion spawn point. 
- It must be a minion that was originally in play in this wave, before being defeated or removed. Dodger cannot “respawn” a minion that was not originally in play at the start of the wave.
 - She must respawn a minion directly onto a spawn point. She cannot respawn the minion on a space adjacent to the spawn point. Note that this is different than respawning minions after the lane pushes.
faq-gar-XgL3MPkL.question: Does Garrus’s Silver (Chilling Howl) slow an enemy moving into radius from outside?
faq-gar-XgL3MPkL.answer: No. Movement restrictions are checked at the beginning of movement, so a hero within Garrus’s radius is affected, but a hero moving into the radius will complete their full movement value.
faq-gar-RuXRiXjv.question: Can Garrus’s Alt Reds (Blunt Force) move away from the attacked hero to another?
faq-gar-RuXRiXjv.answer:
If your attack against an opposing hero does not defeat them, they will still be adjacent to you. There are several valid options for movement:
- You could move to a different space adjacent to the hero you attacked
 - You may move and end the movement adjacent to a different enemy hero.
 - You may move and end the movement adjacent multiple enemy heroes (you can still only choose one of them as your target)
 If you cannot end your movement next to an enemey hero, you cannot move at all after the attack.
faq-gyd-K3e6TuJP.question: Does "Energy Drain" require a non-immune enemy hero in range for my team to be able to regain 1 spent Life counter?
faq-gyd-K3e6TuJP.answer:
Yes, you need to be able to target a hero first.
"If able" after a comma makes the preceding step non-mandatory (p. 17), so it only applies to the "discard" step of the instructions.
faq-mis-9icT8gG7.question: Misa’s Gold “ignores the effects of tokens.” What does that include?
faq-mis-9icT8gG7.answer:
Misa ignores the effects of tokens themselves, but not Actions or Active Effects that use those tokens.
- She would ignore Min’s Mines and Smoke Bomb and Tali’s Ice Tokens. She could still be forced to discard by Min’s Grenade (an Active Effect) or targeted by Wuk’s Primary Red (_Nature’s Protector_), which only requires her to be adjacent to a Tree Token.
faq-mis-872OuVpW.question: What does Misa’s Silver force Heroes to do?
faq-mis-872OuVpW.answer:
The only requirement of Swoop In is that heroes in radius must target Misa with attack actions if she is an eligible target. They would not be forced to target Misa in the following examples:
- An enemy hero may use an attack for another action, such as movement, instead.
- An enemy hero with a targeting restriction on their attack may not be able to target Misa, and would be unaffected. Swift’s Primary Red (_Prepared Shot_) targets a non-adjacent unit. If Swift is adjacent to Misa, she is not allowed to shoot Misa, so she can ignore Swoop In and pick any valid target.
- An enemy hero with movement before their attack may move freely, and then choose a different target — even if they had an option to move and target Misa — as long as Misa is not a valid target after their movement. Tigerclaw’s Gold (_Blink Strike_) moves 2 spaces through a unit and then targets the unit. He could move through and attack a different target, even if Misa would have been an option, since Tigerclaw freely picks his movement before Swoop In restricts his targeting.
- Note that a unit moving into Misa’s radius as part of another action would be affected by Swoop In after their movement. If they target after their movement, and Misa is a valid target, they must target her. Brogan’s Primary Red (_Mad Dash_) moves several spaces and then targets. Brogan can make any valid move, but if he ends in Misa’s radius, he must target her if she is a valid target, even if he began the charge outside of the radius.
faq-mis-gfW2c17j.question: If Misa plays Silver and then discards for some other reason, does she gain coins?
faq-mis-gfW2c17j.answer: Yes. If Misa has Swoop In active, she gains coins for her first discard, regardless of the reason.
faq-mis-kUOh8C68.question: How and why does Misa’s Tier III Red restrict her target so they “cannot choose to not defend”?
faq-mis-kUOh8C68.answer: Misa’s target must discard a card to defend, if able, even if the defense will not be successful. Normally a hero who is unable to defend successfully will not defend at all, to have more cards after respawning — in this case, Misa’s victim is forced to defend unsuccessfully.
faq-mis-c4Vl76z2.question: Does Misa’s Alt Red Push its target?
faq-mis-c4Vl76z2.answer: No. The effect is not a Push, and does not work like a Push. Misa can choose the movement, as long as it ends up in a space farther than it was before the movement.
faq-mis-7y5Ocd8c.question: Misa’s Primary Blue ignores obstacles. Does this ignore tokens?
faq-mis-7y5Ocd8c.answer: Actually, no! “Ignoring Obstacles” means moving freely through them, but their effects are still applied. For example, Min’s Mines would still trigger after she moves through them (an effect of the token).
faq-mis-V58R7KUy.question: If Misa uses Primary Green, can she resolve the same card twice with different actions?
faq-mis-V58R7KUy.answer: No. Misa’s Primary Green repeats an action, it doesn’t play the card twice, so the same action is used on the repeat.
faq-mis-Y7w06Zrr.question: If Misa uses Primary Green to repeat an action, and she plays Silver afterwards, does she gain double the money?
faq-mis-Y7w06Zrr.answer: No. Repeating an action with an Active Effect does not duplicate the Active Effect, so Misa could not gain extra coins for a discard (or multiple discards).
faq-mor-oiXBV41f.question: Can I take Zombie tokens from the board if all Zombie tokens are already in play?
faq-mor-oiXBV41f.answer: Yes. Tokens should come from the Supply first, but if you need to place more tokens than are available in the supply, first remove up to that number of tokens of the same type from the board. Page 18 of the rulebook under "Place" clarifies this in further detail.
faq-mor-VRbthTGv.question: If I cannot defend against an attack, can I still discard this to place the Zombie tokens?
faq-mor-VRbthTGv.answer: Yes. You can always play a card to defend even if the Defense value does not allow you to successfully defend. As this is a Defense/Skill card, you are allowed to place the Zombie tokens. (See p. 14 for more detail.)
faq-neb-QxJOvtUS.question: Interactions with NebKher’s Gold (Mind Grip)?
faq-neb-QxJOvtUS.answer:
This card has lots of weird interactions:
- Mind Grip is only played as a skill action on your turn. You could not use Mind Grip’s copy ability to copy a card while defending.
- Active effects he copies will work normally, as though NebKher’s Gold was an exact copy of the card. The effect remains, even if the originally copied card changes state or the hero is defeated.
- When NebKher copies effects that place tokens, he places Illusion tokens instead. They will not take on the properties of the copied tokens.
- If NebKher copies cards that specifically refer to tokens, NebKher uses those tokens as those heroes would (such as Min’s mines or smoke bombs, or Wuk’s trees).
- NebKher can copy Trinkets’ cards to remove and/or place the Turret.
- If NebKher copies an action that says “this card”, it means the card with the printed ability, not Neb’s. He cannot copy Brogan’s Silver (Bullwark), for example, then retrieve his Gold.
- Although it can copy attacks, Mind Grip is a skill card, so some card resolutions may happen differently. Examples:
     - If NebKher copies a non-ranged attack, he is performing a non-ranged attack (even though his Gold card is a ranged skill). A non-ranged attack he is using could not be blocked by Tigerclaw’s Primary Blue (Dodge) or Wasp’s Primary Green (Stop Projectiles), both of which only block ranged attacks.
- If NebKher copies Igantia’s Silver (Moment of Equilibrium), he will re-set the coin to a side of his choice. (Ignatia only prevents ties from changing it.)
- NebKher cannot copy the card of an immune hero.
faq-neb-lR0UngYk.question: NebKher’s Silver (Diabolical Laughter) says you need to laugh diabolically. Do you really need to laugh diabolically?
faq-neb-lR0UngYk.answer: Of course not: there are 31 other heroes to play. Mwahaha!
faq-neb-nRunMRdC.question: What about units on the line drawn by NebKher’s Alt Blue (Crack in Reality)?
faq-neb-nRunMRdC.answer: Units on the line can affect and be affected by units on both sides.
faq-raz-YvsEXe2a.question: Each instance of Razzle is “the same hero, except when actions are performed.” Is that only when your own actions are performed, or when enemy actions are performed as well?
faq-raz-YvsEXe2a.answer:
During any action, regardless of whether it is performed by your enemy, ally or yourself, all the Razzles other than the active one is considered “another hero”.

Cards such as Mortimer’s Crawling Dead (which let you affect “another enemy hero in radius”) or Xargatha's Cleave (which can be repeated on a “different enemy hero”) can target Razzle twice by targeting two Razzle figures.

It is therefore very important to not have multiple Razzles near a hero that has multi-target discards as it is an easy way to be card killed.
faq-sabina-AR1boyR4.question: Does Sabina gain the attack bonus against Heroes who have played but not resolved an attack card?
faq-sabina-AR1boyR4.answer: Yes: the card only checks for Heroes that **played** an attack card, regardless of whether they’ve resolved the action, which action they performed, and even whether this is still their card for the turn (it will “remember” whether they have played a card, even if it is discarded or switched for another card by an effect).
faq-sabina-842FGqW2.question: How does Sabina’s Tier III Primary Blue card treat friendly minions “as both melee and ranged”?
faq-sabina-842FGqW2.answer: Such minions would apply their penalties to adjacent units and ranged units, giving -2 Defense to an adjacent Hero.
faq-sil-VBPVBU86.question: When can Silverarrow’s Gold Fast Travel?
faq-sil-VBPVBU86.answer:
The Fast Travel has all the normal restrictions of a Fast Travel action: there must be no enemy Heroes or Minions in her Zone, and if not, she can move anywhere in her Zone or to an adjacent Zone with no enemy Heroes or Minions.
_Note that this is a rare instance of a Fast Travel which is not replacing a movement action. Silverarrow could Fast Travel (if valid), even if she cannot move due to another effect._
faq-sil-BNCeD4CM.question: Does Silverarrow’s Primary Blue affect a Hero who moves in range of Silverarrow during their movement?
faq-sil-BNCeD4CM.answer: No, movement restrictions are checked at the beginning of the movement.
faq-sil-4vXYYv56.question: How does the timing of Silverarrow’s Alt Blue relate to immunity that lasts for the turn?
faq-sil-4vXYYv56.answer: Active Effects that trigger at “End of Turn”, such as Silverarrow’s Alt Blue, still happen during the turn. If a Hero is immune during that turn, they are still immune to the discard.
faq-swi-6Iy6RJQH.question: How can Swift's Silver card already be resolved while its action is being performed?
faq-swi-6Iy6RJQH.answer: If this card is played before Swift's Gold card, it will already be resolved when the Gold card triggers it again.
faq-tal-sA6IR13i.question: What happens when Tali’s Gold targets a Hero?
faq-tal-sA6IR13i.answer:
The targeted hero must have an unresolved card. They choose to either return the card to their hand (they will not take an action this turn), or, Tali names a color of card for them to discard, if able.
- An enemy target must pick between losing their action for the turn (retrieving the card) or losing another card of Tali’s choice from hand.
- Targeting friendly heroes, Tali is “over-healing” the hero, keeping an extra card in hand for the round and making them more difficult to kill. (If Tali has and her teammate find that they disagree strategically, the teammate could refuse to return the card. Tali could then safely name that color to prevent them from discarding.)
faq-tal-bgAzAr8M.question: What communication is legal for Tali’s Silver?
faq-tal-bgAzAr8M.answer: All Table Talk and Communication is fully open - to teammates and opponents (p. 4). A Tali player can give teammates instructions like “Say Blue” or “Say Red if Sabina plays Gold, otherwise say Green,” as long as the opponents can hear (and understand) these instructions. The Tali player may _not_ secretly indicate their desire to their teammates by whispering, gestures, showing cards, a private code, etc.
faq-tal-e2Ja6hsd.question: If Tali tries to resolve her Silver and her whole team is dead or immune, what happens?
faq-tal-e2Ja6hsd.answer: No friendly hero can be chosen and the card does nothing.
faq-tal-g9x1Ca07.question: If Tali’s Primary Red or Primary Blue causes a “temporary discard,” but then Tali is defeated, what happens?
faq-tal-g9x1Ca07.answer: The active effect of Tali’s card is canceled, so the opponent never retrieves their card. Through death, Tali scored an extra hit.
faq-tal-pX35L9un.question: How would Tali’s Tier I Primary Green place 1 Ice Token next to another Ice Token?
faq-tal-pX35L9un.answer: Since it only places 1 Ice Token, and they’re removed at the end of the round, it usually can’t. Some copy effects or other weird cases can cause it to happen.
faq-tal-5K1OWmD6.question: Tali’s Alternate Green makes a Totem that can protect a minion. If the Totem is removed, does the Hero gain coins?
faq-tal-5K1OWmD6.answer: No. The Totem is removed instead of the minion being defeated, so no minion is defeated and no coins are gained.
faq-tig-RZOM5aw8.question: Does Tigerclaw’s Gold attack require movement?
faq-tig-RZOM5aw8.answer: Yes! If Tigerclaw cannot move through the target in a straight line, the effect will “fizzle” — stop resolving — and he will not attack. A crafty opponent can anticipate and deny this attack with clever positioning.
faq-tig-VhE684Ew.question: How does Tigerclaw’s Silver card activate?
faq-tig-VhE684Ew.answer: Tigerclaw must begin his turn adjacent to an obstacle (including any unit), then place himself into a space in radius that is not adjacent to an enemy unit. If he does so, he will be immune and can move through units during the next turn. Remember that immunity means he cannot be targeted or affected by any action, can move through tokens (not stop movement on them), and may ignore token effects.
faq-tig-qmf2Koiz.question: Does Tigerclaw’s Primary Green skill require an enemy hero?
faq-tig-qmf2Koiz.answer:
Yes, to perform it completely. After Tigerclaw performs the first movement on the card, it checks for an adjacent enemy hero to steal from. If there is no adjacent enemy hero, the card “fizzles” — stops resolving — and he will not make the final movement. In this case, it is usually better to simply play the card for its movement.
 --- 
There are cases where performing the action without an enemy hero is still advantageous, such as if other effects restrict movement actions (such as Arien’s Alt Blue or Xargatha’s Primary Blue) or other effects will reward him for performing a skill action.
faq-tig-JfrPJWdN.question: What happens if Tigerclaw’s poison reduces a value below 1?
faq-tig-JfrPJWdN.answer:
Values can drop to 0 and even be negative:
- Initiative values are resolved in the normal order from highest to lowest.
- Negative defense values are calculated normally and may still block an attack if the Defense Total is greater than or equal to the Attack Total.
- Negative Attack Totals will still defeat a Minion and must still be defended against (or will defeat the hero).
faq-tri-Gy7gS7zz.question: What is the Turret?
faq-tri-Gy7gS7zz.answer: It’s an obstacle and counts as terrain. It’s not a unit, minion, or hero, and it doesn’t do anything other than as instructed by Trinkets’ cards. The Turret’s presence and counting as terrain are properties, not an active effect, so they don’t change if Trinkets’ cards change zones, between rounds, or if Trinkets dies. You’re limited to the single provided Turret, so placing a Turret while it’s already on the map will reposition it, not add a Turret. Several of Trinkets’ effects require a target in range of Trinkets and the Turret, measuring the range of both of these independently.
faq-tri-Q91NHrfO.question: How do Trinkets cards target?
faq-tri-Q91NHrfO.answer:
Several of Trinkets cards target based on the location of the Turret. While thematically the Turret is shooting them, Trinkets is still the one playing these cards, targeting enemies, etc.: the Turret only provides a targeting restriction. Therefore:
- Arien’s Silver (Spell Break) could prevent a nearby Trinkets from using skills like Primary Blue (Disruptor Jolt) or Alt Green (Self-Destruct), even if the Turret is far away.
- Min’s Silver (Smoke Bomb) can interrupt a Trinkets attack if the Smoke Bomb is between Trinkets and the taret, irrespective of the position of the Turret.
faq-urs-ib4a4DV0.question: If Ursafar discards Silver to defend, is he still enraged?
faq-urs-ib4a4DV0.answer: Yes. Primary Defense (or Defense/Skill) actions resolve their text, including Active Effects, even if they end up in the Discard Pile. (Note that if it later changes state, the Active Effect is canceled.)
faq-urs-znPgp2l0.question: Does Ursafar gain coins for removing a minion on his Primary Red?
faq-urs-znPgp2l0.answer: No. Coins are only gained for defeating a Minion, not Removing one.
faq-urs-reTuR399.question: When Ursafar’s Alternate Blue is Active, can Heroes move next to him? Can they move away from him?
faq-urs-reTuR399.answer: Yes. Enemy Heroes cannot move through spaces adjacent to Ursafar. As the reminder text on Tier II indicates, they can move into or out of an adjacent space, but not both.
faq-urs-Il223e44.question: Would Ursafar’s Ultimate allow him to move using his Silver?
faq-urs-Il223e44.answer: No. The second effect on Angry Roar, +2 Movement, will only increase the Movement value of a card which already has a Movement Action.
faq-wasp-W273D7Gg.question: How does Wasp’s Gold card work?
faq-wasp-W273D7Gg.answer:
After attacking, any enemy Heroes adjacent to you cancel their active effects. Active effects have bold text saying “Next turn:”, “This round:”, etc. and are turned sideways. This includes Active effects that are not yet in effect (for example, Min’s Alt Blue, (_Death Grenade_), is an “End of turn:” Active effect that would still be canceled and not happen). Additionally, for the rest of the turn, enemy Heroes next to you cannot perform skill actions (the primary action on skill cards). This is checked on their turn, so if the Hero is no longer adjacent to you, they would be able to perform skill actions again.
• Wasp’s Gold can “interrupt” a skill that moves a hero next to Wasp (like Tigerclaw’s Primary Green, _Master Thief_): they will not be able to perform the rest of the action.
faq-wasp-P8qD2hsM.question: How does Wasp’s Silver card work?
faq-wasp-P8qD2hsM.answer:
Static Barrier divides the map into 2 regions: spaces within its radius and outside its radius. Enemy units cannot **move** or **fast travel** across the “barrier” between the two regions:
- ❌They **cannot** take a move action (to move or fast travel) to move across the barrier.
- ❌They **cannot** use an attack or skill involving movement to cross the barrier.
- ❌They **cannot** cross the barrier on their path, even if they cross back. That is, a hero outside the barrier cannot walk into the radius and then walk back out.
- ✅They **can** use a “place” or “swap” effect (such as Arien’s Alt Blue) to cross the barrier.
- ✅They **can** be pushed across the barrier (pushing is not movement) or moved by another player’s card.
faq-wasp-iOUfdU2P.question: How do Wasp’s Primary Blue cards move units and tokens?
faq-wasp-iOUfdU2P.answer: The target cannot move farther away or closer, so the distance between you and the target must remain unchanged.
faq-wasp-6LS6R1fC.question: When does Wasp’s Alternative Blue cards force a discard?
faq-wasp-6LS6R1fC.answer: This card pushes adjacent enemies away from you (in a straight line). If an enemy Hero cannot be pushed the full distance, because an obstacle is located along the straight line path, the Hero is forced to discard.
faq-wasp-uCXB6YGe.question: Why do Wasp’s Tier II and III Primary Green cards say “If you do”? Why would the block fail?
faq-wasp-uCXB6YGe.answer: You can always discard a card to attempt to Defend, even if it does not Defend successfully. In this case, the Block’s condition must be met (the attacker is not adjacent) in order to apply the second half of the card (forcing the attacker to discard).
faq-whi-TDtkq39W.question: When Whisper plays Gold against an enemy Hero, how do they move?
faq-whi-TDtkq39W.answer: First, the targeted Hero chooses and discards a Card of their choice (if they have any cards remaining in hand). If they do so and the discarded Card has a movement value, that Hero must then move that distance in a straight line. They would only be unable to do so (and therefore stay on the same space) if they could not move the full movement value in a straight line in any of the 6 directions from their current space.
faq-whi-q4y88H3C.question: Does Whisper’s Silver require the condition be maintained to keep him immune to attacks?
faq-whi-q4y88H3C.answer: No. If Whisper has an enemy Hero with a discarded card in radius when Death Seeker is played, he can activate attack immunity for the round, even if the enemy moves away later.
faq-whi-a08G4w4S.question: Can Whisper’s Tier III Alt Red target a Minion ​​first and then repeat on a Hero?
faq-whi-a08G4w4S.answer: Yes. “Different Hero” means “different unit, which is a hero.”
faq-whi-3W6mQ7QY.question: Does Whisper’s Primary Blue move Minions in the same absolute direction (“Northwest”) or relative to Whisper (“away from Whisper”)? How many spaces can they move?
faq-whi-3W6mQ7QY.answer: They all move in the same absolute direction. Whisper may choose how many spaces each minion moves.
faq-whi-2Sh4CgpI.question: How does Whisper’s Alternate Blue resolve? Can they pick an option that does nothing?
faq-whi-2Sh4CgpI.answer:
Whisper’s Alternate Blue requires targeting an enemy Hero in range or it will fizzle and have no effect. That Hero then picks one of the two options, regardless of whether they will have any effect. In other words, the card won’t “work” unless Whisper is adjacent to a Minion.
 Note that on Tier III, Whisper can target 3 minions simultaneously. He cannot use this action to defeat the last non-Heavy Minion at the same time as the Heavy.
faq-wuk-O48Zw7g2.question: When moving through a heavy minion and another one, does the order of minions matter?
faq-wuk-O48Zw7g2.answer: "Up to two minions" resolves at the same time, so the heavy minion cannot be targeted and will not be defeated.
faq-xar-81t69G1Q.question: How does Xargatha’s Gold card work?
faq-xar-81t69G1Q.answer: After attacking, this card creates an active effect for the rest of the turn. After Xargatha is made to discard, she can resolve the primary action of an attack card in her discard (since Gold is active, this will be Red). In effect, attacking Xargatha or forcing her to discard might grant her an extra attack.
faq-xar-nMZ2b17x.question: Can Xargatha’s Silver card be repeated on the same unit?
faq-xar-nMZ2b17x.answer:
Yes. If it’s still the nearest non-immune enemy unit, and isn’t yet adjacent, the same target can be pulled up to 4 spaces.
- If the target is unable to be moved, for example, if it is in the radius of a friendly Brogan’s Silver, then the effect will try and fail to move the target, twice.
faq-xar-uxm2IDQl.question: What do Xargatha's Primary Blue cards affect and not affect?
faq-xar-uxm2IDQl.answer:
It prevents “movement actions”, that is, selecting the movement option when resolving a card:
 - ❌ They **can’t** use a normal movement action to move.
 - ❌ They **can’t** use a movement action to fast travel (which chooses, then replaces, a movement action).
 - ✅ They **can** use a “place” or “swap” effect (such as Arien’s Alt Blue).
 - ✅ They **can** be pushed or moved by another effect (if the effect ignores immunity).
 - ✅ They **can** take another action type that involves movement (such as Brogan’s Primary Red) or a Fast Travel (Silverarrow’s Gold).
Note that this effect differs from Xargatha’s Alternative Green cards.
faq-xar-BBNWEowq.question: What do Xargatha’s Alternative Green cards affect and not affect?
faq-xar-BBNWEowq.answer:
It prevents movement except for using the cards listed, but there are some corner cases:
• They can’t use a normal movement action to move, except using a Gold (TII/III) or Red (TII only) card.
• They can’t use a movement action to fast travel (which chooses, then replaces, a movement action), except for the card colors.
• They can’t move as part of another card text. If the ability they choose includes movement, the effect would “fizzle” — stop resolving. For example, Brogan’s Primary Red requires movement before attacking, so he would not be able to move and attack this way. (Against the TII effect, he could resolve a movement action with his red card, but not the attack.)
• They can use a “place” or “swap” effect (such as Arien’s Alt Blue).
• The can be pushed or moved by another effect.
• They can take another action type that explicitly involves Fast Travel (Silverarrow’s Gold).
Note that this effect differs from Xargatha’s Primary Blue cards.
faq-xar-8b9y16Gi.question: What modifiers do Xargatha’s Primary Green cards affect?
faq-xar-8b9y16Gi.answer: The Primary Green says “when calculating defense totals”, but remember that this includes Minions friendly to the attacker and defender. Enemy minions will help Xargatha’s team attack other Heroes and defend against them.
faq-common-OmbzNwt1.question: What does immunity protect from?
faq-common-OmbzNwt1.answer:
Basically everything. An immune unit can’t be targeted or affected by any action. They can choose to move through and ignore tokens.
Beware that conditional immunity only applies when the sources of an effect matches the condition (eg. “immune to enemy attack actions”)
faq-common-J6uK9mGB.question: Why is there a range 1 attack? Isn’t that non-ranged?
faq-common-J6uK9mGB.answer:
A range of 1 can only target an adjacent space (but the range may be increased by items or other effects). A range of 0 has no targets.
Some cards **explicitly** interact with ranged or non-ranged attacks.
faq-common-5eb64zdk.question: Is Fast Travel the same thing as movement?
faq-common-5eb64zdk.answer:
No. Fast Travel is a special type of action that usually replaces a Movement action. They are related but different:

- When you would take a Movement action, you can fast travel instead.
- If you use a primary Movement action to Fast Travel, you would ignore the card text, since you are replacing the action.
- A card that lets you move (“Move 2 spaces…”) would not let you Fast Travel instead.
- If you are prevented from moving or from taking a Movement action, you could not use a Movement action to Fast Travel.
- If you are limited in how you move (“May only move 1 space”), you may still Fast Travel as normal, since you are allowed to select, then replace, the Movement action (and Fast Travel is a placement, not movement).
faq-common-Xe16hzf0.question: Does my effect trigger next round?
faq-common-Xe16hzf0.answer: No. Active effects always “clear” at the end of the round: A “next turn” effect played on Turn 4 will **not** carry over to the next round.
faq-common-Xe16hz1a.question: What are Obstacles?
faq-common-Xe16hz1a.answer: Obstacles are basically anything on the map: Units (Heroes and Minions), terrain shown on the map, tokens, and any other miniatures. There can only be one Obstacle on each space, and Obstacles generally can’t move through each other. If an ability does allow Obstacles to pass through each other (“you can move through Obstacles”, ignore Obstacles”, “Heroes may move through a space with a tree token”), they still may not end movement on such a space.
faq-common-fizzle.question: Can I play an action if only some of its instructions can be performed?
faq-common-fizzle.answer:
You **must** follow the cards instructions step by step, starting from the top.
- If you cannot perform the first instruction (e.g., there is no valid target in range, or you cannot make the required movement), you may not perform the action at all.
- After the first instruction is successfully exectued, you continue resolving the rest of the instructions in order.
- If you reach an instruction that is not optional and you cannot perform it, the action immediately **fizzles** — no further instructions are resolved. You place the card on your hero dashboard, and your turn ends.
_See page 10 of the rulebook for additional reference._
